body:
### Problem

As the title says. Here is also the [start](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/start) documentation. Also I believe https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36635 to be related or this may help get that resolved.

Essentially, executing

```
:call system('cmd.exe /c start "" "C:\\Program Files"')
```
works but the other options

```
:lua =vim.system({'cmd.exe', '/c', 'start', '""', '"C\\:Program Files"'})
:lua vim.fn.system('cmd.exe /c start "" "C:\\Program Files"')
```
do not work.

Also `vim.system()` does work without the quotes parameter,

```
lua =vim.system({'cmd.exe', '/c', 'start', 'C:\\'})

```

Some extra info: `start` always uses the first argument as the title of the Command Prompt window it tries to open. Therefore these commands in the Command Prompt,

```
cmd.exe /c start C:\
cmd.exe /c start "C:\Program Files"
```
would not have same effect since in the second one, `start` would open a Command Prompt window with that title. For that command to be valid you would have to do,

```
cmd.exe /c start "" "C:\Program Files"
```
This also means that to use `start` universally for opening files, directories, URLs, etc. you need to use it as above. 

Looking at my issue at https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36635 it appears that `start` is a viable option for it to be resolved, but this issue needs to be solved before that to ensure that `start` can accept all inputs. I am also not sure how the `vim.cmd()` call would look like if you want to use that method, because you need to place three things in quotes and escaping doesn't seem to work...



### Steps to reproduce

1. Open Neovim
2.  Execute `:lua =vim.system({'cmd.exe', '/c', 'start', '""', '"C\\:Program Files"'})`
3. Execute `:lua vim.fn.system('cmd.exe /c start "" "C:\\Program Files"')`
4. Execute `:call system('cmd.exe /c start "" "C:\\Program Files"')`
5. Last one will work, others won't

### Expected behavior

For the corresponding file or folder to open

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

0.11.5

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

N/A

### Operating system/version

Windows 11

### Terminal name/version

Windows Terminal

### $TERM environment variable

N/A

### Installation

winget
title: Windows: `cmd.exe /c start "" "C:\Program Files"` Command does not work with `vim.system()` or `vim.fn.system()`  but works with  `:call system()`
